00290| class SecureCookieSessionInterface(SessionInterface):
00291|     """The default session interface that stores sessions in signed cookies
00292|     through the :mod:`itsdangerous` module.
00293|     """
00294|     #: the salt that should be applied on top of the secret key for the
00295|     #: signing of cookie based sessions.
00296|     salt = 'cookie-session'
00297|     #: the hash function to use for the signature.  The default is sha1
00298|     digest_method = staticmethod(hashlib.sha1)
00299|     #: the name of the itsdangerous supported key derivation.  The default
00300|     #: is hmac.
00301|     key_derivation = 'hmac'
00302|     #: A python serializer for the payload.  The default is a compact
00303|     #: JSON derived serializer with support for some extra Python types
00304|     #: such as datetime objects or tuples.
00305|     serializer = session_json_serializer
00306|     session_class = SecureCookieSession
00307| 
00308|     def get_signing_serializer(self, app):
00309|         if not app.secret_key:
00310|             return None
00311|         signer_kwargs = dict(
00312|             key_derivation=self.key_derivation,
00313|             digest_method=self.digest_method
00314|         )
00315|         return URLSafeTimedSerializer(app.secret_key, salt=self.salt,
00316|                                       serializer=self.serializer,
00317|                                       signer_kwargs=signer_kwargs)
00318| 
00319|     def open_session(self, app, request):
00320|         s = self.get_signing_serializer(app)
00321|         if s is None:
00322|             return None
00323|         val = request.cookies.get(app.session_cookie_name)
00324|         if not val:
00325|             return self.session_class()
00326|         max_age = total_seconds(app.permanent_session_lifetime)
00327|         try:
00328|             data = s.loads(val, max_age=max_age)
00329|             return self.session_class(data)
00330|         except BadSignature:
00331|             return self.session_class()
00332| 
00333|     def save_session(self, app, session, response):
00334|         domain = self.get_cookie_domain(app)
00335|         path = self.get_cookie_path(app)
00336| 
00337|         # Delete case.  If there is no session we bail early.
00338|         # If the session was modified to be empty we remove the
00339|         # whole cookie.
00340|         if not session:
00341|             if session.modified:
00342|                 response.delete_cookie(app.session_cookie_name,
00343|                                        domain=domain, path=path)
00344|             return
00345| 
00346|         # Modification case.  There are upsides and downsides to
00347|         # emitting a set-cookie header each request.  The behavior
00348|         # is controlled by the :meth:`should_set_cookie` method
00349|         # which performs a quick check to figure out if the cookie
00350|         # should be set or not.  This is controlled by the
00351|         # SESSION_REFRESH_EACH_REQUEST config flag as well as
00352|         # the permanent flag on the session itself.
00353|         if not self.should_set_cookie(app, session):
00354|             return
00355| 
00356|         httponly = self.get_cookie_httponly(app)
00357|         secure = self.get_cookie_secure(app)
00358|         expires = self.get_expiration_time(app, session)
00359|         val = self.get_signing_serializer(app).dumps(dict(session))
00360|         response.set_cookie(app.session_cookie_name, val,
00361|                             expires=expires, httponly=httponly,
00362|                             domain=domain, path=path, secure=secure)

00122| .. class:: request
00123| 
00124|    To access incoming request data, you can use the global `request`
00125|    object.  Flask parses incoming request data for you and gives you
00126|    access to it through that global object.  Internally Flask makes
00127|    sure that you always get the correct data for the active thread if you
00128|    are in a multithreaded environment.

00130|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.

00133|    subclass and provides all of the attributes Werkzeug defines.  This
00134|    just shows a quick overview of the most important ones.

00156| Sessions
00157| --------
00158| 
00159| If you have the :attr:`Flask.secret_key` set you can use sessions in Flask
00160| applications.  A session basically makes it possible to remember
00161| information from one request to another.  The way Flask does this is by
00162| using a signed cookie.  So the user can look at the session contents, but
00163| not modify it unless they know the secret key, so make sure to set that
00164| to something complex and unguessable.
00165| 
00166| To access the current session you can use the :class:`session` object:
00167| 
00168| .. class:: session
00169| 
00170|    The session object works pretty much like an ordinary dict, with the
00171|    difference that it keeps track on modifications.
00172| 
00173|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00174| 
00175|    The following attributes are interesting:
00176| 
00177|    .. attribute:: new
00178| 
00179|       `True` if the session is new, `False` otherwise.
00180| 
00181|    .. attribute:: modified
00182| 
00183|       `True` if the session object detected a modification.  Be advised
00184|       that modifications on mutable structures are not picked up
00185|       automatically, in that situation you have to explicitly set the
00186|       attribute to `True` yourself.  Here an example::
00187| 
00188|           # this change is not picked up because a mutable object (here
00189|           # a list) is changed.
00190|           session['objects'].append(42)
00191|           # so mark it as modified yourself
00192|           session.modified = True
00193| 
00194|    .. attribute:: permanent
00195| 
00196|       If set to `True` the session lives for
00197|       :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` seconds.  The
00198|       default is 31 days.  If set to `False` (which is the default) the
00199|       session will be deleted when the user closes the browser.
00200|

00205| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00206| 
00207| The session interface provides a simple way to replace the session
00208| implementation that Flask is using.

00227| .. autodata:: session_json_serializer
00228| 
00229|    This object provides dumping and loading methods similar to simplejson
00230|    but it also tags certain builtin Python objects that commonly appear in
00231|    sessions.  Currently the following extended values are supported in
00232|    the JSON it dumps:
00233| 
00234|    -    :class:`~markupsafe.Markup` objects

00242|    starting with Flask 0.8.  Either catch this down yourself or use
00243|    the :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` attribute on the

00256| Application Globals
00257| -------------------
00258| 
00259| .. currentmodule:: flask
00260| 
00261| To share data that is valid for one request only from one function to
00262| another, a global variable is not good enough because it would break in
00263| threaded environments.  Flask provides you with a special object that
00264| ensures it is only valid for the active request and that will return
00265| different values for each request.  In a nutshell: it does the right
00266| thing, like it does for :class:`request` and :class:`session`.
00267| 
00268| .. data:: g
00269| 
00270|    Just store on this whatever you want.  For example a database
00271|    connection or the user that is currently logged in.
00272| 
00273|    Starting with Flask 0.10 this is stored on the application context and
00274|    no longer on the request context which means it becomes available if
00275|    only the application context is bound and not yet a request.  This
00276|    is especially useful when combined with the :ref:`faking-resources`
00277|    pattern for testing.
00278| 
00279|    Additionally as of 0.10 you can use the :meth:`get` method to
00280|    get an attribute or `None` (or the second argument) if it's not set.
00281|    These two usages are now equivalent::
00282| 
00283|         user = getattr(flask.g, 'user', None)
00284|         user = flask.g.get('user', None)
00285| 
00286|    It's now also possible to use the ``in`` operator on it to see if an
00287|    attribute is defined and it yields all keys on iteration.
00288| 
00289|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.

00345| JSON Support
00346| ------------
00347| 
00348| .. module:: flask.json
00349| 
00350| Flask uses ``simplejson`` for the JSON implementation.  Since simplejson
00351| is provided both by the standard library as well as extension Flask will
00352| try simplejson first and then fall back to the stdlib json module.  On top
00353| of that it will delegate access to the current application's JSON encoders
00354| and decoders for easier customization.
00355| 
00356| So for starters instead of doing::
00357| 
00358|     try:
00359|         import simplejson as json
00360|     except ImportError:
00361|         import json
00362| 
00363| You can instead just do this::
00364| 
00365|     from flask import json
00366| 
00367| For usage examples, read the :mod:`json` documentation in the standard
00368| library.  The following extensions are by default applied to the stdlib's
00369| JSON module:
00370| 
00371| 1.  ``datetime`` objects are serialized as :rfc:`822` strings.
00372| 2.  Any object with an ``__html__`` method (like :class:`~flask.Markup`)
00373|     will have that method called and then the return value is serialized
00374|     as string.
00375| 
00376| The :func:`~htmlsafe_dumps` function of this json module is also available
00377| as filter called ``|tojson`` in Jinja2.  Note that inside `script`
00378| tags no escaping must take place, so make sure to disable escaping
00379| with ``|safe`` if you intend to use it inside `script` tags unless
00380| you are using Flask 0.10 which implies that:
00381| 
00382| .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00383| 
00384|     <script type=text/javascript>
00385|         doSomethingWith({{ user.username|tojson|safe }});
00386|     </script>
00387|

00606| .. _url-route-registrations:
00607| 
00608| URL Route Registrations
00609| -----------------------
00610| 
00611| Generally there are three ways to define rules for the routing system:
00612| 
00613| 1.  You can use the :meth:`flask.Flask.route` decorator.
00614| 2.  You can use the :meth:`flask.Flask.add_url_rule` function.
00615| 3.  You can directly access the underlying Werkzeug routing system
00616|     which is exposed as :attr:`flask.Flask.url_map`.
00617| 
00618| Variable parts in the route can be specified with angular brackets
00619| (``/user/<username>``).  By default a variable part in the URL accepts any
00620| string without a slash however a different converter can be specified as
00621| well by using ``<converter:name>``.
00622| 
00623| Variable parts are passed to the view function as keyword arguments.
00624| 
00625| The following converters are available:
00626| 
00627| =========== ===============================================
00628| `string`    accepts any text without a slash (the default)
00629| `int`       accepts integers
00630| `float`     like `int` but for floating point values
00631| `path`      like the default but also accepts slashes
00632| =========== ===============================================
00633| 
00634| Here are some examples::
00635| 
00636|     @app.route('/')
00637|     def index():
00638|         pass
00639| 
00640|     @app.route('/<username>')
00641|     def show_user(username):
00642|         pass
00643| 
00644|     @app.route('/post/<int:post_id>')
00645|     def show_post(post_id):
00646|         pass
00647| 
00648| An important detail to keep in mind is how Flask deals with trailing
00649| slashes.  The idea is to keep each URL unique so the following rules
00650| apply:
00651| 
00652| 1. If a rule ends with a slash and is requested without a slash by the
00653|    user, the user is automatically redirected to the same page with a
00654|    trailing slash attached.
00655| 2. If a rule does not end with a trailing slash and the user requests the
00656|    page with a trailing slash, a 404 not found is raised.
00657| 
00658| This is consistent with how web servers deal with static files.  This
00659| also makes it possible to use relative link targets safely.
00660| 
00661| You can also define multiple rules for the same function.  They have to be
00662| unique however.  Defaults can also be specified.  Here for example is a
00663| definition for a URL that accepts an optional page::
00664| 
00665|     @app.route('/users/', defaults={'page': 1})
00666|     @app.route('/users/page/<int:page>')
00667|     def show_users(page):
00668|         pass
00669| 
00670| This specifies that ``/users/`` will be the URL for page one and
00671| ``/users/page/N`` will be the URL for page `N`.
00672| 
00673| Here are the parameters that :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` and
00674| :meth:`~flask.Flask.add_url_rule` accept.  The only difference is that
00675| with the route parameter the view function is defined with the decorator
00676| instead of the `view_func` parameter.
00677| 
00678| =============== ==========================================================
00679| `rule`          the URL rule as string
00680| `endpoint`      the endpoint for the registered URL rule.  Flask itself
00681|                 assumes that the name of the view function is the name
00682|                 of the endpoint if not explicitly stated.
00683| `view_func`     the function to call when serving a request to the
00684|                 provided endpoint.  If this is not provided one can
00685|                 specify the function later by storing it in the
00686|                 :attr:`~flask.Flask.view_functions` dictionary with the
00687|                 endpoint as key.
00688| `defaults`      A dictionary with defaults for this rule.  See the
00689|                 example above for how defaults work.
00690| `subdomain`     specifies the rule for the subdomain in case subdomain
00691|                 matching is in use.  If not specified the default
00692|                 subdomain is assumed.
00693| `**options`     the options to be forwarded to the underlying
00694|                 :class:`~werkzeug.routing.Rule` object.  A change to
00695|                 Werkzeug is handling of method options.  methods is a list
00696|                 of methods this rule should be limited to (`GET`, `POST`
00697|                 etc.).  By default a rule just listens for `GET` (and
00698|                 implicitly `HEAD`).  Starting with Flask 0.6, `OPTIONS` is
00699|                 implicitly added and handled by the standard request
00700|                 handling.  They have to be specified as keyword arguments.
00701| =============== ==========================================================
00702| 
00703| .. _view-func-options:
00704| 
00705| View Function Options
00706| ---------------------
00707| 
00708| For internal usage the view functions can have some attributes attached to
00709| customize behavior the view function would normally not have control over.
00710| The following attributes can be provided optionally to either override
00711| some defaults to :meth:`~flask.Flask.add_url_rule` or general behavior:
00712| 
00713| -   `__name__`: The name of a function is by default used as endpoint.  If
00714|     endpoint is provided explicitly this value is used.  Additionally this
00715|     will be prefixed with the name of the blueprint by default which
00716|     cannot be customized from the function itself.
00717| 
00718| -   `methods`: If methods are not provided when the URL rule is added,
00719|     Flask will look on the view function object itself is an `methods`
00720|     attribute exists.  If it does, it will pull the information for the
00721|     methods from there.
00722| 
00723| -   `provide_automatic_options`: if this attribute is set Flask will
00724|     either force enable or disable the automatic implementation of the
00725|     HTTP `OPTIONS` response.  This can be useful when working with
00726|     decorators that want to customize the `OPTIONS` response on a per-view
00727|     basis.
00728| 
00729| -   `required_methods`: if this attribute is set, Flask will always add
00730|     these methods when registering a URL rule even if the methods were
00731|     explicitly overridden in the ``route()`` call.
00732| 
00733| Full example::
00734| 
00735|     def index():
00736|         if request.method == 'OPTIONS':
00737|             # custom options handling here
00738|             ...
00739|         return 'Hello World!'
00740|     index.provide_automatic_options = False
00741|     index.methods = ['GET', 'OPTIONS']
00742| 
00743|     app.add_url_rule('/', index)
00744| 
00745| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00746|    The `provide_automatic_options` functionality was added.
00747|

00001| Upgrading to Newer Releases
00002| ===========================
00003| 
00004| Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
00005| the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
00006| anything in your code to profit from a new release.
00007| 
00008| However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
00009| changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
00010| improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
00011| Flask.
00012| 
00013| This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
00014| release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
00015| updating experience.
00016| 
00017| If you want to use the `easy_install` command to upgrade your Flask
00018| installation, make sure to pass it the ``-U`` parameter::
00019| 
00020|     $ easy_install -U Flask
00021| 
00022| .. _upgrading-to-010:
00023| 
00024| Version 0.10
00025| ------------
00026| 
00027| The biggest change going from 0.9 to 0.10 is that the cookie serialization
00028| format changed from pickle to a specialized JSON format.  This change has
00029| been done in order to avoid the damage an attacker can do if the secret
00030| key is leaked.  When you upgrade you will notice two major changes: all
00031| sessions that were issued before the upgrade are invalidated and you can
00032| only store a limited amount of types in the session.  The new sessions are
00033| by design much more restricted to only allow JSON with a few small
00034| extensions for tuples and strings with HTML markup.
00035| 
00036| In order to not break people's sessions it is possible to continue using
00037| the old session system by using the `Flask-OldSessions`_ extension.
00038| 
00039| Flask also started storing the :data:`flask.g` object on the application
00040| context instead of the request context.  This change should be transparent
00041| for you but it means that you now can store things on the ``g`` object
00042| when there is no request context yet but an application context.  The old
00043| ``flask.Flask.request_globals_class`` attribute was renamed to
00044| :attr:`flask.Flask.app_ctx_globals_class`.
00045| 
00046| .. _Flask-OldSessions: http://packages.python.org/Flask-OldSessions/
00047| 
00048| Version 0.9
00049| -----------
00050| 
00051| The behavior of returning tuples from a function was simplified.  If you
00052| return a tuple it no longer defines the arguments for the response object
00053| you're creating, it's now always a tuple in the form ``(response, status,
00054| headers)`` where at least one item has to be provided.  If you depend on
00055| the old behavior, you can add it easily by subclassing Flask::
00056| 
00057|     class TraditionalFlask(Flask):
00058|         def make_response(self, rv):
00059|             if isinstance(rv, tuple):
00060|                 return self.response_class(*rv)
00061|             return Flask.make_response(self, rv)
00062| 
00063| If you maintain an extension that was using :data:`~flask._request_ctx_stack`
00064| before, please consider changing to :data:`~flask._app_ctx_stack` if it makes
00065| sense for your extension.  For instance, the app context stack makes sense for
00066| extensions which connect to databases.  Using the app context stack instead of
00067| the request stack will make extensions more readily handle use cases outside of
00068| requests.
00069| 
00070| Version 0.8
00071| -----------
00072| 
00073| Flask introduced a new session interface system.  We also noticed that
00074| there was a naming collision between `flask.session` the module that
00075| implements sessions and :data:`flask.session` which is the global session
00076| object.  With that introduction we moved the implementation details for
00077| the session system into a new module called :mod:`flask.sessions`.  If you
00078| used the previously undocumented session support we urge you to upgrade.
00079| 
00080| If invalid JSON data was submitted Flask will now raise a
00081| :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.BadRequest` exception instead of letting the
00082| default :exc:`ValueError` bubble up.  This has the advantage that you no
00083| longer have to handle that error to avoid an internal server error showing
00084| up for the user.  If you were catching this down explicitly in the past
00085| as `ValueError` you will need to change this.
00086| 
00087| Due to a bug in the test client Flask 0.7 did not trigger teardown
00088| handlers when the test client was used in a with statement.  This was
00089| since fixed but might require some changes in your testsuites if you
00090| relied on this behavior.
00091| 
00092| Version 0.7
00093| -----------
00094| 
00095| In Flask 0.7 we cleaned up the code base internally a lot and did some
00096| backwards incompatible changes that make it easier to implement larger
00097| applications with Flask.  Because we want to make upgrading as easy as
00098| possible we tried to counter the problems arising from these changes by
00099| providing a script that can ease the transition.
00100| 
00101| The script scans your whole application and generates an unified diff with
00102| changes it assumes are safe to apply.  However as this is an automated
00103| tool it won't be able to find all use cases and it might miss some.  We
00104| internally spread a lot of deprecation warnings all over the place to make
00105| it easy to find pieces of code that it was unable to upgrade.
00106| 
00107| We strongly recommend that you hand review the generated patchfile and
00108| only apply the chunks that look good.
00109| 
00110| If you are using git as version control system for your project we
00111| recommend applying the patch with ``path -p1 < patchfile.diff`` and then
00112| using the interactive commit feature to only apply the chunks that look
00113| good.
00114| 
00115| To apply the upgrade script do the following:
00116| 
00117| 1.  Download the script: `flask-07-upgrade.py
00118|     <https://raw.github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/master/scripts/flask-07-upgrade.py>`_
00119| 2.  Run it in the directory of your application::
00120| 
00121|         python flask-07-upgrade.py > patchfile.diff
00122| 
00123| 3.  Review the generated patchfile.
00124| 4.  Apply the patch::
00125| 
00126|         patch -p1 < patchfile.diff
00127| 
00128| 5.  If you were using per-module template folders you need to move some
00129|     templates around.  Previously if you had a folder named ``templates``
00130|     next to a blueprint named ``admin`` the implicit template path
00131|     automatically was ``admin/index.html`` for a template file called
00132|     ``templates/index.html``.  This no longer is the case.  Now you need
00133|     to name the template ``templates/admin/index.html``.  The tool will
00134|     not detect this so you will have to do that on your own.
00135| 
00136| Please note that deprecation warnings are disabled by default starting
00137| with Python 2.7.  In order to see the deprecation warnings that might be
00138| emitted you have to enabled them with the :mod:`warnings` module.
00139| 
00140| If you are working with windows and you lack the `patch` command line
00141| utility you can get it as part of various Unix runtime environments for
00142| windows including cygwin, msysgit or ming32.  Also source control systems
00143| like svn, hg or git have builtin support for applying unified diffs as
00144| generated by the tool.  Check the manual of your version control system
00145| for more information.
00146| 
00147| Bug in Request Locals
00148| `````````````````````
00149| 
00150| Due to a bug in earlier implementations the request local proxies now
00151| raise a :exc:`RuntimeError` instead of an :exc:`AttributeError` when they
00152| are unbound.  If you caught these exceptions with :exc:`AttributeError`
00153| before, you should catch them with :exc:`RuntimeError` now.
00154| 
00155| Additionally the :func:`~flask.send_file` function is now issuing
00156| deprecation warnings if you depend on functionality that will be removed
00157| in Flask 1.0.  Previously it was possible to use etags and mimetypes
00158| when file objects were passed.  This was unreliable and caused issues
00159| for a few setups.  If you get a deprecation warning, make sure to
00160| update your application to work with either filenames there or disable
00161| etag attaching and attach them yourself.
00162| 
00163| Old code::
00164| 
00165|     return send_file(my_file_object)
00166|     return send_file(my_file_object)
00167| 
00168| New code::
00169| 
00170|     return send_file(my_file_object, add_etags=False)
00171| 
00172| .. _upgrading-to-new-teardown-handling:
00173| 
00174| Upgrading to new Teardown Handling
00175| ``````````````````````````````````
00176| 
00177| We streamlined the behavior of the callbacks for request handling.  For
00178| things that modify the response the :meth:`~flask.Flask.after_request`
00179| decorators continue to work as expected, but for things that absolutely
00180| must happen at the end of request we introduced the new
00181| :meth:`~flask.Flask.teardown_request` decorator.  Unfortunately that
00182| change also made after-request work differently under error conditions.
00183| It's not consistently skipped if exceptions happen whereas previously it
00184| might have been called twice to ensure it is executed at the end of the
00185| request.
00186| 
00187| If you have database connection code that looks like this::
00188| 
00189|     @app.after_request
00190|     def after_request(response):
00191|         g.db.close()
00192|         return response
00193| 
00194| You are now encouraged to use this instead::
00195| 
00196|     @app.teardown_request
00197|     def after_request(exception):
00198|         if hasattr(g, 'db'):
00199|             g.db.close()
00200| 
00201| On the upside this change greatly improves the internal code flow and
00202| makes it easier to customize the dispatching and error handling.  This
00203| makes it now a lot easier to write unit tests as you can prevent closing
00204| down of database connections for a while.  You can take advantage of the
00205| fact that the teardown callbacks are called when the response context is
00206| removed from the stack so a test can query the database after request
00207| handling::
00208| 
00209|     with app.test_client() as client:
00210|         resp = client.get('/')
00211|         # g.db is still bound if there is such a thing
00212| 
00213|     # and here it's gone
00214| 
00215| Manual Error Handler Attaching
00216| ``````````````````````````````
00217| 
00218| While it is still possible to attach error handlers to
00219| :attr:`Flask.error_handlers` it's discouraged to do so and in fact
00220| deprecated.  In general we no longer recommend custom error handler
00221| attaching via assignments to the underlying dictionary due to the more
00222| complex internal handling to support arbitrary exception classes and
00223| blueprints.  See :meth:`Flask.errorhandler` for more information.
00224| 
00225| The proper upgrade is to change this::
00226| 
00227|     app.error_handlers[403] = handle_error
00228| 
00229| Into this::
00230| 
00231|     app.register_error_handler(403, handle_error)
00232| 
00233| Alternatively you should just attach the function with a decorator::
00234| 
00235|     @app.errorhandler(403)
00236|     def handle_error(e):
00237|         ...
00238| 
00239| (Note that :meth:`register_error_handler` is new in Flask 0.7)
00240| 
00241| Blueprint Support
00242| `````````````````
00243| 
00244| Blueprints replace the previous concept of “Modules” in Flask.  They
00245| provide better semantics for various features and work better with large
00246| applications.  The update script provided should be able to upgrade your
00247| applications automatically, but there might be some cases where it fails
00248| to upgrade.  What changed?
00249| 
00250| -   Blueprints need explicit names.  Modules had an automatic name
00251|     guesssing scheme where the shortname for the module was taken from the
00252|     last part of the import module.  The upgrade script tries to guess
00253|     that name but it might fail as this information could change at
00254|     runtime.
00255| -   Blueprints have an inverse behavior for :meth:`url_for`.  Previously
00256|     ``.foo`` told :meth:`url_for` that it should look for the endpoint
00257|     `foo` on the application.  Now it means “relative to current module”.
00258|     The script will inverse all calls to :meth:`url_for` automatically for
00259|     you.  It will do this in a very eager way so you might end up with
00260|     some unnecessary leading dots in your code if you're not using
00261|     modules.
00262| -   Blueprints do not automatically provide static folders.  They will
00263|     also no longer automatically export templates from a folder called
00264|     `templates` next to their location however but it can be enabled from
00265|     the constructor.  Same with static files: if you want to continue
00266|     serving static files you need to tell the constructor explicitly the
00267|     path to the static folder (which can be relative to the blueprint's
00268|     module path).
00269| -   Rendering templates was simplified.  Now the blueprints can provide
00270|     template folders which are added to a general template searchpath.
00271|     This means that you need to add another subfolder with the blueprint's
00272|     name into that folder if you want ``blueprintname/template.html`` as
00273|     the template name.
00274| 
00275| If you continue to use the `Module` object which is deprecated, Flask will
00276| restore the previous behavior as good as possible.  However we strongly
00277| recommend upgrading to the new blueprints as they provide a lot of useful
00278| improvement such as the ability to attach a blueprint multiple times,
00279| blueprint specific error handlers and a lot more.
00280| 
00281| 
00282| Version 0.6
00283| -----------
00284| 
00285| Flask 0.6 comes with a backwards incompatible change which affects the
00286| order of after-request handlers.  Previously they were called in the order
00287| of the registration, now they are called in reverse order.  This change
00288| was made so that Flask behaves more like people expected it to work and
00289| how other systems handle request pre- and postprocessing.  If you
00290| depend on the order of execution of post-request functions, be sure to
00291| change the order.
00292| 
00293| Another change that breaks backwards compatibility is that context
00294| processors will no longer override values passed directly to the template
00295| rendering function.  If for example `request` is as variable passed
00296| directly to the template, the default context processor will not override
00297| it with the current request object.  This makes it easier to extend
00298| context processors later to inject additional variables without breaking
00299| existing template not expecting them.
00300| 
00301| Version 0.5
00302| -----------
00303| 
00304| Flask 0.5 is the first release that comes as a Python package instead of a
00305| single module.  There were a couple of internal refactoring so if you
00306| depend on undocumented internal details you probably have to adapt the
00307| imports.
00308| 
00309| The following changes may be relevant to your application:
00310| 
00311| -   autoescaping no longer happens for all templates.  Instead it is
00312|     configured to only happen on files ending with ``.html``, ``.htm``,
00313|     ``.xml`` and ``.xhtml``.  If you have templates with different
00314|     extensions you should override the
00315|     :meth:`~flask.Flask.select_jinja_autoescape` method.
00316| -   Flask no longer supports zipped applications in this release.  This
00317|     functionality might come back in future releases if there is demand
00318|     for this feature.  Removing support for this makes the Flask internal
00319|     code easier to understand and fixes a couple of small issues that make
00320|     debugging harder than necessary.
00321| -   The `create_jinja_loader` function is gone.  If you want to customize
00322|     the Jinja loader now, use the
00323|     :meth:`~flask.Flask.create_jinja_environment` method instead.
00324| 
00325| Version 0.4
00326| -----------
00327| 
00328| For application developers there are no changes that require changes in
00329| your code.  In case you are developing on a Flask extension however, and
00330| that extension has a unittest-mode you might want to link the activation
00331| of that mode to the new ``TESTING`` flag.
00332| 
00333| Version 0.3
00334| -----------
00335| 
00336| Flask 0.3 introduces configuration support and logging as well as
00337| categories for flashing messages.  All these are features that are 100%
00338| backwards compatible but you might want to take advantage of them.
00339| 
00340| Configuration Support
00341| `````````````````````
00342| 
00343| The configuration support makes it easier to write any kind of application
00344| that requires some sort of configuration.  (Which most likely is the case
00345| for any application out there).
00346| 
00347| If you previously had code like this::
00348| 
00349|     app.debug = DEBUG
00350|     app.secret_key = SECRET_KEY
00351| 
00352| You no longer have to do that, instead you can just load a configuration
00353| into the config object.  How this works is outlined in :ref:`config`.
00354| 
00355| Logging Integration
00356| ```````````````````
00357| 
00358| Flask now configures a logger for you with some basic and useful defaults.
00359| If you run your application in production and want to profit from
00360| automatic error logging, you might be interested in attaching a proper log
00361| handler.  Also you can start logging warnings and errors into the logger
00362| when appropriately.  For more information on that, read
00363| :ref:`application-errors`.
00364| 
00365| Categories for Flash Messages
00366| `````````````````````````````
00367| 
00368| Flash messages can now have categories attached.  This makes it possible
00369| to render errors, warnings or regular messages differently for example.
00370| This is an opt-in feature because it requires some rethinking in the code.
00371| 
00372| Read all about that in the :ref:`message-flashing-pattern` pattern.
00373|

===========================

Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
anything in your code to profit from a new release.

However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
Flask.

This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
updating experience.

If you want to use the `easy_install` command to upgrade your Flask
installation, make sure to pass it the ``-U`` parameter::

00757| .. admonition:: How to generate good secret keys
00758| 
00759|    The problem with random is that it's hard to judge what is truly random.  And
00760|    a secret key should be as random as possible.  Your operating system
00761|    has ways to generate pretty random stuff based on a cryptographic
00762|    random generator which can be used to get such a key:

00764|    >>> import os
00765|    >>> os.urandom(24)
00766|    '\xfd{H\xe5<\x95\xf9\xe3\x96.5\xd1\x01O<!\xd5\xa2\xa0\x9fR"\xa1\xa8'
00767|

00776| 
00777| Message Flashing
00778| ----------------
00779| 
00780| Good applications and user interfaces are all about feedback.  If the user
00781| does not get enough feedback they will probably end up hating the
00782| application.  Flask provides a really simple way to give feedback to a
00783| user with the flashing system.  The flashing system basically makes it
00784| possible to record a message at the end of a request and access it on the next
00785| (and only the next) request.  This is usually combined with a layout
00786| template to expose the message.
00787| 
00788| To flash a message use the :func:`~flask.flash` method, to get hold of the
00789| messages you can use :func:`~flask.get_flashed_messages` which is also
00790| available in the templates.  Check out the :ref:`message-flashing-pattern`
00791| for a full example.
00792| 
00793| Logging
00794| -------
00795| 
00796| .. versionadded:: 0.3
00797| 
00798| Sometimes you might be in a situation where you deal with data that
00799| should be correct, but actually is not.  For example you may have some client-side
00800| code that sends an HTTP request to the server but it's obviously
00801| malformed.  This might be caused by a user tampering with the data, or the
00802| client code failing.  Most of the time it's okay to reply with ``400 Bad
00803| Request`` in that situation, but sometimes that won't do and the code has
00804| to continue working.
00805| 
00806| You may still want to log that something fishy happened.  This is where
00807| loggers come in handy.  As of Flask 0.3 a logger is preconfigured for you
00808| to use.
00809| 
00810| Here are some example log calls::
00811| 
00812|     app.logger.debug('A value for debugging')
00813|     app.logger.warning('A warning occurred (%d apples)', 42)
00814|     app.logger.error('An error occurred')
00815| 
00816| The attached :attr:`~flask.Flask.logger` is a standard logging
00817| :class:`~logging.Logger`, so head over to the official `logging
00818| documentation <http://docs.python.org/library/logging.html>`_ for more
00819| information.
00820| 
00821| Hooking in WSGI Middlewares
00822| ---------------------------
00823| 
00824| If you want to add a WSGI middleware to your application you can wrap the
00825| internal WSGI application.  For example if you want to use one of the
00826| middlewares from the Werkzeug package to work around bugs in lighttpd, you
00827| can do it like this::
00828| 
00829|     from werkzeug.contrib.fixers import LighttpdCGIRootFix
00830|     app.wsgi_app = LighttpdCGIRootFix(app.wsgi_app)
00831|
